inputs.text: Pamela,  Where do you get the numbers for the EEMC tab? Here are the stages of the process that I currently know about:     1) EES sends the schedule  file to the EPMI server   2) Calf. schedulers pull EES schedules into their portfolio and submit the information to the ISO.   3) ISO sends back Day Ahead Finals (Changes could occur with EES original schedule)   4) ISO Sends back Hour Ahead Finals (Changes could occur with EES schedule from the Day Ahead Market)   As you can see, there is quite a few places that changes can occur to an EES schedule in the course of a day. So I am trying to follow the information flow on both the EES side and the EPMI side. If the only schedule you see is the one that is originally sent to the  EPMI server, then I can see where we have the potential to have many unexplained variances. If this is the case, this may be nothing more than providing you with the incremental information that is provided by the ISO during the course of a given day. Just update me on your process flow, and I will keep this issue moving along until completion.          Thanks           Chris     To: Chris Stokley/HOU/ECT@ECT cc:   Subject: Re: HA Final Schedules for EES & PGES for 03/26 - 0403     Chris,  the spreadsheet below contains the HA_Finals that you send to me(EPMI) as well as the scheduled volumes sent from the scheduling group(EES).  The volumes on the EPMI tab is inconsistent with the EEMC tab.  Please review the variance sheet tab which will denote the days, zone and hours where the difference occur.    I am assuming the EPMI numbers are incorrect because of the hour by hour consistency on the EEMC  spreadsheet.  However,  this assumption could be incorrect.   Again, please review and let me know.   Thanks,  Pam       <Embedded StdOleLink>
outputs.inference: Pamela, Where do you get the numbers for the EEMC tab? Here are the stages of the process that I currently know about: 1) EES sends the schedule file to the EPMI server 2) Calf. schedulers pull EES schedules into their portfolio and submit the information to

inputs.text: OUTLOOK EMAIL NOTIFICATION  Your Date of Migration is: April 18th  YOU WILL BE UNABLE TO SEND E-MAIL unless you take the following action: Please go through your Notes email and clean out as many old/un-needed email items as possible BEFORE your date of migration.  After you are migrated to Outlook you will only be allocated 100MB of total Mailbox space.   If more than this amount of data is migrated to Outlook YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO SEND E-MAIL until it is below the 100MB limit.  Cleaning up your Notes email now will prevent this from happening to YOU.  Enron's messaging platform is migrating from Lotus Notes to Microsoft Outlook 2000 worldwide.  You will be accessing Outlook for all of your email functions.   WHY IS ENRON MIGRATING TO OUTLOOK 2000?  Many factors contributed to the decision to migrate from Lotus Notes to Microsoft Exchange/Outlook.  The most prominent factors were:  ? Significant advantages to moving to a product that is more integrated with current Enron apps (Windows 2000, Office and Internet Explorer) ? More efficient Shared PC and Roaming User features ? Improved support and integration for Palm/CE devices ? Instant Messaging capabilities  WHAT IS BEING MIGRATED TO OUTLOOK 2000?  ? Email Messages.  From the date of your scheduled migration, the last (30) thirty days of your Email will be converted for use in Outlook. ? All your folders in Notes you use to store email messages in. ? To Do Items ? Journal Items ? Calendar Entries dating from (1) one year in the past to (10) ten years in the future will be converted. ? Address Books, but NOT your Distribution Lists that you created.  You will need to re-create these in Outlook.  Thank you,  Outlook 2000 Migration Team
outputs.inference: OUTLOOK EMAIL NOTIFICATION Your Date of Migration is: April 18th. YOU WILL BE UNABLE TO SEND E-MAIL unless you take the following action: Please go through your Notes email and clean out as many old/un-needed email items as possible BE
